@drcrallen is there a doc for router besides  docs/content/Router.md
 , I've already updated that.
@himanshug : I might be taking crazy pills, but I don't see `druid.router.http.numMaxThreads`  in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/docs/content/Router.md or any of the other docs.
Since it is part of the general http client config now, it will also impact the broker settings.

@drcrallen it is not part of general http client config but only the http client used in AsyncQueryForwardingServlet at router
and I've updated Router.md in this PR documenting the new setting.

@himanshug : It can be accessed under `druid.global.http` via `JettyHttpClientModule` and `HttpClientModule` as well as `druid.broker.http` via `HttpClientModule` via `Initialization.makeInjectorWithModules` and lastly as `druid.router.http` via `CliRouter`

@drcrallen yes, from code point of view

but, from user perspective, only place that is using this setting is AsyncQueryForwardingServlet (though other nodes can choose to use it at some point) , changing that setting only affects router proxy servlet http client and nothing else.

druid has support for native FilteredAggregator where you can specify a filter (using and,or and selector) and your aggregator. for more details refer to - http://druid.io/docs/latest/Aggregations.html

The injector creation workflow usually goes through cusotom Druid Guice handlings rather than making a Guice injector using Guice directly.
`io.druid.initialization.Initialization.makeInjectorWithModules` for example.

These are setup during the CLI launching workflow.

Guice injection in a unit test is a PITA right now.

There doesn't seem to be a straightforward way to test this using junit/surefire.

It might be possible to use an integration test where we vary a bunch of options. I at least added the default recommended parameters to the general surefire command (excluding tmpdir)

@cheddar Unless you're actually calling the methods in `io.druid.cli.Main` you cannot say you are replicating exactly what happens with initial Guice injection. You can say that you are close, or that you capture the intended workflow, but you are not using the same workflow.

I don't fully understand why "make objectMapper eager to ensure jackson gets setup with guice injection for JsonConfigurator" is no longer a relevant concern. But the PR is in so there's not much use in dwelling on it.
@infynyxx tests failed for unrelated reason, merging.

@drcrallen I trust @cheddar on this one, since he initially wrote the Guice injection bootstrapping and it hasn't changed much since. I assume this has been tested standalone and we'll have to make sure it doesn't break any of the examples or extensions being able to register jackson types.

@b-slim @cheddar since you are working on making things more pluggable, it would be really cool if you could write some documentation on pluggable things, e.g. showing how you can build your own emitter module. Maybe we can add a section for that to the documentation revamp.
@xvrl That sounds a good idea, will try to write some doc about it.

@b-slim Just an FYI, if you've been following the Druid proposals, I am currently making gigantic changes to docs right now. It may be a good idea to wait until my changes are in before making any doc changes on your side.

I think we need to test this PR a bit more to understand if the possible benefits justify the code complexity. I also think we should make sure that persists will not be starved out with these changes.
Aside from a few "?"s (and me commenting on the commit instead of the PR... sorry), this looks generally in line with my comments.

Regarding eliminating `.gz` code: it is used in some of the QTL stuff.

This PR is a baby step towards giving a more generic and standard interface between data. If I could pull in hadoop's abstract File handling without encountering Hadoop dependency hell I would.

On the decompress thing.  I think it can make sense to have the semantics be "give me the directory to decompress files into" and in the gzip case, it keeps the original file name without the `.gz` (similar to what the unix `gunzip` does).  For zip, it just unzips into the directory.
well, but my need is to caculate the number according to the dims, not like make new Aggregator  with other Aggregators.

Relevant log line:

```
2015-03-31T05:15:02,022 INFO [main] io.druid.guice.JsonConfigurator - Loaded class[class io.druid.segment.loading.LocalDataSegmentPusherConfig] from props[druid.storage.] as [io.druid.segment.loading.LocalDataSegmentPusherConfig@4d3ca6c7]
```

After adding `"io.druid.extensions:druid-s3-extensions"`:

```
2015-03-31T05:16:56,239 INFO [main] io.druid.guice.JsonConfigurator - Loaded class[class io.druid.storage.s3.S3DataSegmentPusherConfig] from props[druid.storage.] as [io.druid.storage.s3.S3DataSegmentPusherConfig@15c4af7a]
```

I did simple tests, and when running a local firehose (so just firing off events as fast as they can be parsed from TPCH file) then the realtime index task runs in about 20% LESS TIME (good) to get to the first persist-n-merge when the persist and the merge thread pools are LOW priority as compared to NORM. Executing any queries on the nodes tends to have no measurable impact on the total ingestion time on my local machine (<50% cpu usage for ingest, persist, merge, and query all combined).

I did not wait for the persist-n-merge to complete. The reason is that looking at the thread breakout, the persist and realtime index task (plumber) are the ones that run concurrently, with the merge task running all by its lonesome.

This is on my Mac though, so mileage on Linux may vary since the schedulers are not exactly the same.

Thanks for the contrib! Do you mind filling out our CLA: druid.io/community/cla.html

I'll merge the PR after that.

@janakg Sorry for the delay. A few comments:
1) There is a mixture of the query path and the flow of data in the diagram, but the flow of data is not fully illustrated. If we choose to display both, I think we should include the flow for segment handoff.
2) The handoff process consists of compacting intermediate segments and creating the final merged segment, uploading the segment to deep storage, writing and entry in the metadata store, having the coordinator pick up info about the segment, having the coordinator assign the segment to historicals via zookeeper, having historicals download the segment, having realtimes notice the segment is now served by historicals, and having realtimes drop the segment.
3) I don't think this diagram should go into example production configuration as it involves Kafka and Samza/Storm, which are not required to run Druid. I think after I rework the documentation, there will be a more mature place for this diagram.

Incorporated these changes manually
From a high level I'm curious if a load queue and a drop queue actors and fewer locks would make sense instead of this map-based-quasi-queue

Single threaded loading of segments was done intentionally in order to simplify the ability to reason about how resources are going to be needed.  Doing this is going to cause the ability for stampedes to happen that slow down query performance.

:-1:
There's a bunch of extra gunk on this PR because it was used for discussion early on.  Can you close and re-open?
@cheddar : are you worried about disk-io or simple user-time contention?
@cheddar : sure
Making fresh PR for code review.
@cheddar : https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1259

@nishantmonu51, @cheddar and I discussed this a little bit offline and came to the following conclusion that we think should address everyone's concerns.

The main issue we are trying to address is the ability to speedup downloading of segments when spinning up new nodes. Currently this can take tens of hours on very large clusters, because network bandwidth cannot be fully utilized, which makes adjustment of replication strategies (e.g. when adding tiers), or replacing all the hardware for an entire cluster (e.g. when AWS decides to reboot your entire cluster for patches) unnecessarily time-consuming.

We don't want parallelized segment loading to adversely impact query performance at any cost, so we should only allow parallelization of segment loading during the initialization phase.  By default we should leave it single threaded, similar to what we do for segment cache initialization.
At query time, we should limit the number of loading threads to 1. In case someone really really wants to sacrifice 1 or 2 processing threads, and use them for loading on a 32 core machine, they should be able to do so, but we won't make that explicitly configurable, requiring overriding the config via extensions instead, to make it clear this is not something we condone.

To summarize, we should:
- make parallelization of segment loading during configurable for init phase
- default to single threaded loading during init phase to preserve the existing behavior
- have a hard-coded setting for number of loading threads post-initialization, set to 1
- allow overriding of the hard-coded setting via guice injection overrides.

Does that sound reasonable to everyone?

One extra thing, on the "init phase loading", it likely might make sense to add something that allows you to fire up a historical node as a "replica" of some other historical nodes.  I.e. on first startup, it looks at what some current historical node(s) are serving and just loads itself up with those segments as fast as possible.

having parallel segment loading during init-phase sounds good to me as it wont affect the query performance and also decrease the node init time significantly. 
I can still see one problem with performance, when we add a new node to a tier, during its init phase queries for complete tier will slow down (as the query time is bounded by the slowest historical node).
A workaround can be to not send queries to a node until its initialized (may be decrease the priority of a node during init-phase.) 

Also, right now we do not have a well defined Lifecycle of a node and no init-phase as well,
I think the two problems of blacklisting nodes and fast init-phase may be related to node lifecycle and can be handled easily if we introduce the concept of lifecycle and state of a node.

This is strange, I had the opposite tests, where using fastestInstance was much faster than fastestJavaInstance

Can you test this on EC2 and see if the results are the same?

In general, can we stay away from JNI/JNA/native bindings that aren't behind some extension point?  Native bindings and native compilation are generally deployment-specific concerns that I don't think we want to get into.  I.e. they are great for extensions.
I agree with @cheddar on this.

@cheddar  / @himanshug : I'm not clear on your conclusion from your statement. The JNI bindings are NOT provided by a druid extension, but are part of the library we link in (`net.jpountz.lz4`). Are you saying if the library uses them it is or it is not ok?

@xvrl My understanding is that LZ4Factory.fastestInstance() uses some JNI bindings while LZ4Factory.fastestJavaInstance() gives a fully java based instance. I agreed that in general situations like these we should probably stick to the java version because there might be os specific gotchas with jni version.

@himanshug fastestInstance() returns a native instance if it can be loaded, otherwise it falls back to doing the same thing as fastestJavaInstance(). If the behavior is substantially different on different OSes I think it makes sense to default to whatever works best on 64-bit linux and to provide an option for other folks. But if whatever works on 64-bit linux works well enough everywhere else we probably don't need an option.

@gianm ok. thanks for explaining " fastestInstance() returns a native instance if it can be loaded, otherwise it falls back to doing the same thing as fastestJavaInstance()" I did not know that.

but, then, we should really report/confirm all our perf numbers from a linux machine instead of mac because with things like this numbers coming from a mac might not be valid really.

"real" benchmarks shouldn't be done on your laptop anyways:
https://metamarkets.com/2015/effect-of-frequency-governor-on-java-benchmarking/
@drcrallen that post looks interesting, unfortunately i'll have to go offline for a while now, i will read it later :)

First query, use a not null dimension "sensor_name" and second query, check null dimension "dot11_protocol". First query not return empty result, but the second query return empty result.

I hope this helps, 

Andres

What is the use case for this? This is cool though.

Currently we always overwrite jars on hdfs if they are snapshot versions, in order to allow non-released versions to be updated. For self-contained jars however, it does not work, because they end in SNAPSHOT-selfcontained.jar, and not just SNAPSHOT.jar

Here's what the benchmarks look like on a Linux 64 bit machine for topN on columns with varying cardinalities and number of aggregators. Each query was run 100 times.

Using Java 1.7.0_76, there is at least 12-18% speedup for lower cardinality columns using native LZ4, but no significant benefit for higher cardinality columns.

```
          query        column aggs       p_value mean_lz4java mean_lz4native    pct_lower    pct_upper
1 doubleSumTopN    a_shipmode    1 1.454267e-100     309.4821       262.5335 -0.158744942 -0.144655872
2 doubleSumTopN    a_shipmode    3 8.499783e-182     497.3100       408.4430 -0.181349668 -0.176041030
3 doubleSumTopN b_receiptdate    1 2.185527e-103     368.8530       323.5018 -0.128511626 -0.117392408
4 doubleSumTopN b_receiptdate    3  2.359603e-19     593.0961       507.7452 -0.172198765 -0.115616011
5 doubleSumTopN     z_comment    1  9.387717e-01    1920.7178      1920.3028 -0.005756513  0.005324385
6 doubleSumTopN     z_comment    3  2.642022e-01    2718.8936      2706.7272 -0.012358087  0.003408603
```

Using Java 1.8.0_40, there is an 8-14% speedup using native LZ4 on lower cardinality columns, but either no difference or in some instances a 2% slow-down on higher cardinality columns.

```
          query        column aggs       p_value mean_lz4java mean_lz4native   pct_lower    pct_upper
1 doubleSumTopN    a_shipmode    1  1.597221e-79     286.8817       255.8193 -0.11496347 -0.101588864
2 doubleSumTopN    a_shipmode    3 8.212182e-168     462.5641       397.2833 -0.14362074 -0.138635764
3 doubleSumTopN b_receiptdate    1  5.184680e-73     348.0832       317.1902 -0.09475385 -0.082749811
4 doubleSumTopN b_receiptdate    3  2.025586e-15     555.9573       489.2676 -0.14735063 -0.092558991
5 doubleSumTopN     z_comment    1  3.366043e-12    1699.6842      1738.5175  0.01687979  0.028814889
6 doubleSumTopN     z_comment    3  1.820116e-02    2437.2691      2410.8006 -0.01984767 -0.001872146
```
